Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Igor Rapinchuk is "Abstract Homomorphisms and Other Problems in the Theory of Algebraic Groups." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Barry Mazur.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, PI Igor Rapinchuk investigated a variety of problems at the meeting ground of group theory, the theory of algebraic groups, representation theory, the theory of division algebras, and Galois cohomology. One part of the project was concerned with the study of abstract representations of the groups of rational points of algebraic groups, together with applications to character varieties of finitely generated groups. Two particularly notable results obtained by the PI are the following. First, he showed that any Q-defined affine algebraic variety can be realized as the complement of the trivial representation in the character variety of a suitable Kazhdan group. He also obtained  a rigidity theorem for arbitrary representations of elementary groups over the coordinate rings of smooth affine curves over number rings; one corollary is that all finite-dimensional complex representations of SL_n(Z[X]), for n at least 3, have a standard description, which provides the first examples of finitely generated linear groups other than arithmetic groups/lattices for which rigidity holds unconditionally.

 

In the second part of the project, the PI focused on the problem of to what extent a finite-dimensional central division algebra is determined by its maximal subfields, and, more generally, to what extent an absolutely almost simple algebraic group is determined by the isomorphism classes of its maximal tori over the field of definition. In colloboration with V.I. Chernousov and A.S. Rapinchuk, the PI showed that if K is a finitely generated field and D is a finite-dimensional central division algebra over K of degree prime to char K, then there are finitely many isomorphism classes of finite-dimensional central division algebras D' over K having the same maximal subfields as D; moreover, if K is the function field of a smooth projective curve C over a number field, one has an explicit upper bound on the number of such D'. The PI and his collaborators have also initiated a general program for analyzing analogous questions for arbitrary absolutely almost simple algebraic groups over finitely generated fields, which is closely tied to the study of groups having good reduction at a suitable set of discrete valuations of the base field. 

 

The PI's work in this project has brought together several areas of mathematics:  in addition to the theory of algebraic groups, it uses techniques from algebraic K-theory, number theory, and arithmetic geometry. The results obtained in this project have also had an impact on other areas: for example, results on character varieties have numerous applications to questions in topology, while the questions on division algebras that were investigated by the PI initially arose in connection with some problems in differential geometry, and their resolution is likely to have interesting consequences in these areas.
